claims.claim: Every prison should have a pre reentry program preparing inmates for release.
claims.quote: every prison should have a what? A pre reentry program that's preparing them anywhere from two to three years, preparing them to go home.

claims.claim: Pre reentry programs should connect inmates with resources and actively involve them in preparation for returning home.
claims.quote: That means connecting with the resources, getting actively involved.

claims.claim: Returning citizens should have access to contact volunteers and staff readily for support.
claims.quote: So we go into prison, talk to them, give them the directory, give them my, I give them my personal cell phone, emails, all of that. They can call me.

claims.claim: Proper funding is essential for reentry programs to provide jobs and better serve incarcerated and returning individuals.
claims.quote: if they fund us properly, see we, all of the people that work on our staff are ex-offenders.

claims.claim: Ex-offenders are the best suited to work with returning citizens because of their shared experiences.
claims.quote: The reason that we hire ex-offenders is because ex-offenders know how to handle other ex-offenders.

claims.claim: Professional qualifications do not necessarily equip an individual to support returning citizens effectively.
claims.quote: If you hire somebody, I don't master degree PhD college degree and they've never been there. Yeah. And they don't know how to handle this man or this woman who is suffering from a mental illness of post-traumatic prison disorder.

claims.claim: Improper handling of returning citizens by unexperienced staff can escalate into crises.
claims.quote: This person handles him like he handles the people in the street and creates a problem or a dilemma that may eventually get outta control or it turned into something else.
